questions.text: Which of the following is an example of disability limitation for polio?

choices.text: Polio immunization drives for infants to reduce the occurence.
Arranging for schooling for a child suffering from residual polio paralysis.
Resting the limbs affected by polio in neutral position.
Providing calipers for walking to patients affected by polio.

questions.solution:
Resting the limbs affected by polio in a neutral position is an example of disability limitation. It is an intervention done to either halt or prevent the transition of the disease process from impairment to handicap.

Rehabilitation has been defined as the use of medical, social, educational, and vocational measures for training the individual to the highest possible level of functional ability. Like providing calipers for walking to patients and arranging schooling after being affected by polio.

Immunization drives are examples of specific protection.

questions.text: A person is involved in unsafe sexual practices. Which of the following viruses is least likely to get transmitted via this route?
questions.solution:
Hepatitis E has feco-oral or waterborne transmission. It does not transmit sexually. Transmission of Hepatitis A, C, and D can occur sexually.

Transmission of the hepatitis A virus can occur from any sexual activity with an infected person and is not limited to fecal-oral contact. People who are sexually active are considered at risk for hepatitis A if they are MSM, live with or are having sex with an infected person, or inject drugs.

questions.text: For how long is Hepatitis A excreted in the feces?

choices.text: One week before the symptoms appear
Two weeks after the symptoms appear
Two weeks before the symptoms and two weeks thereafter
One week before the symptoms and one week thereafter

questions.solution:
HAV is excreted in the feces for about 2 weeks before the onset of jaundice and for up to 2 weeks thereafter.

The risk of transmitting is greatest at 2 weeks before to 1 week after the onset of jaundice.

questions.text: An intern sustains a needlestick injury while drawing blood from a Hepatitis B positive patient. Assuming he has been infected, which among the following will be the first to rise?
questions.solution:
HbsAg is the first serological marker to be detected in Hepatitis B infection.

Related Pearl: Interpretation of common serologic patterns in hepatitis B infection

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman is rushed to the hospital with labor pains at 34 weeks of gestation. She did not attend any prior antenatal visits. On further evaluation, she is found to be positive for HbsAg. Which of the following should be administered to the newborn after delivery?

choices.text: Immunoglobulin, followed by vaccine 1 month later

questions.solution:
The simultaneous administration of hepatitis B immunoglobulin (HBIG) and hepatitis B vaccine is more efficacious than HBIG alone for the¬†prevention of the carrier state in newborn babies of HBV-positive mothers.

HBIG does not interfere with the antibody response to the hepatitis B vaccine.¬†This combined procedure is ideal both for postexposure prophylaxis of persons accidentally exposed to blood known to contain hepatitis B virus and for the¬†prevention of the carrier state in the newborn babies of carrier mothers.

HBIG (0.05‚Äì0.07 mL/kg) IM¬†

  • As early as possible, preferably within 24 hours of exposure

Hepatitis B vaccine (20 mcg/1.0 mL), IM

  • 1st dose: within 7 days of exposure
  • 2nd and 3rd dose: at one and six months, respectively

questions.text:
HCV screening is done for which of the following people?

1. A 19-year-old boy with a history of IV drug abuse.
2. A 30-year-old commercial sex worker who was diagnosed with HIV.
3. A 47-year-old man who received a blood transfusion 32 years ago.
4. A 62-year-old woman with CKD recently started on hemodialysis.
5. A 20-year-old hemophiliac man regularly receiving clotting factor concentrates.
questions.solution:
Patients with a history of IV drug abuse, HIV, and a history of blood transfusion 32 years ago are screened for HCV.

Since the screening of blood for Hepatitis C was started after 1992, hence people who have received a blood transfusion before 1992 (in this MCQ, the year is 1992 in point 3) have to be screened.

HCV screening is done for people who may be at risk for infection. These include:

  • People who received blood, blood products, or organs before screening for hepatitis C virus was implemented
  • Current or former injecting drug users
  • People on long-term hemodialysis
  • Health-care workers
  • People living with HIV
  • People with abnormal liver tests or liver disease
  • Infants born to infected mothers.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about Rotavirus?

choices.text: Severe rotavirus infections are limited to children aged 5-7 years.
Rotavirus is shed in high concentrations for several days in the stools and vomit of infected children.
Rotavirus diarrhoea increases in frequency during drier, cooler months.
Clean water supplies and good hygiene are unlikely to have a substantial effect on viral transmission.

questions.solution:
Severe rotavirus gastroenteritis is largely limited to children aged 6-24 months, not 5-7 years.

Rotavirus is the leading cause of severe, dehydrating diarrhea in children aged <5 years globally.¬†In developing countries, 75% of the children acquire their first rotavirus infection in the first 12 months.

The universal occurrence of rotavirus infections shows that clean water supply and good hygiene are unlikely to have a substantial effect on virus transmission.¬†In tropical areas, rotavirus diarrhea occurs throughout the year, increasing in frequency in drier, cooler climates.

Transmission is through the¬†feco-oral route, person-to-person contact, or indirectly through fomites. Infected individuals shed very high concentrations of the virus¬†for many days in their stool and vomit.

questions.text: A mother brought a 2 month old child with complaints of diarrhea and vomiting. As a part of management, you advise her regarding vaccination for rotavirus.  Which is the false statement regarding the same?

choices.text: Rotarix is administered in 2 oral doses.
It cannot be given in an immunocompromised child.
The first dose of Rotarix is contraindicated for infants <12 weeks.
It is not a part of catchup vaccination programmes due to its risk of intussusception.

questions.solution:
The first dose of the Rotarix vaccine is contraindicated for infants > 12 weeks of age due to the potential risk of intussusception. Hence, it is not a part of catch-up immunization programs as the age is difficult to ascertain in such programs.

Rotavirus vaccines are live, attenuated, and are administered orally. So, it is not given to an immunocompromised child.

Given below are the different Rotavirus vaccines available along with their schedule:

Vaccines Number of doses Interval between doses Maximum age limit
Rotarix 2

6 weeks

10 weeks

12 weeks

24 weeks
RotaTeq 3 8, 16, 24 weeks 32 weeks
Rotavac 3 6, 10, 14 weeks 32 weeks
Rotasil 3 6, 10, 14 weeks 1 year

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false for carriers of cholera?

choices.text: A convalescent carrier may continue to excrete vibrios for 2-3 weeks.
The gall bladder is infected in chronic carriers.
The antibody titres of a contact carrier is normal while the stool culture is positive.

questions.solution:
The antibody titers of all carriers are risen and positive till the person harbors the organism. 

A cholera carrier is defined as an apparently healthy person excreting V.cholerae O1 in stools. Selective media and enrichment is needed for their diagnosis. In cholera, 4 types of carriers are described.

  1. Incubatory/Pre-Clinical carriers: The duration of carrier state is 1-5 days (incubation period). They present with symptoms later.
  2. Convalescent carriers: Recovered from an attack of cholera, continues to excrete vibrios for 2-3 weeks, due to ineffective antibiotic treatment.
  3. Contact/Health carrier: Due to subclinical infection contracted through a case or an infected environment, may excrete for 10 days.
  4. Chronic carriers: Gallbladder is infected, duration may be as long as 10 years.

questions.text: A convalescent carrier of cholera will remain infectious for how many days after recovery?
questions.solution:
A convalescent carrier of cholera will remain infectious for 14-21 days after recovery.

This type of carrier continues to excrete vibrios after being recovered from an attack of cholera. It is seen due to ineffective antibiotic treatment. These carriers can often become chronic or long-term carriers.

questions.text: A child is brought to the PHC with acute diarrhea. The doctor based on the history suspects that the child may be suffering from an infection due to shigella over cholera. Which of the following points on the history, apart from bloody stools, favors the doctor's suspicion?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the presence of fever favors the suspicion towards Shigella as the infectious agent.

The absence of rectal pain and the presence of vomiting favors cholera while abdominal cramps are present in both of these conditions.

Symptomatic differential diagnosis of shigella and cholera:

Symptoms Cholera Shigella
Diarrhea Acute watery Acute bloody
Fever No Yes
Abdominal cramps Yes Yes
Vomiting Yes No
Rectal pain No Yes
Stool >3 loose stools per day, watery like rice water > 3 stools/day, with blood or pus.

¬†

questions.text: Which of the following guidelines will you follow to treat a child diagnosed with cholera?

choices.text: A cardiotonic should be added if shock persists even after treating with iv fluids.
If the diarrhoea persists after 48 hours of treatment, suspect resistance.
Antidiarrheals and antiemetics should be started.

questions.solution:
In patients with cholera, if diarrhea persists after 48 hours of antibiotic therapy, resistance to the antibiotic should be suspected.

Treatment for cholera:

  • Rehydration therapy - is started immediately, either oral or intravenous.
  • Antibiotic therapy - As soon as vomiting has stopped (usually after 3-4 hours of rehydration). Fluoroquinolones, tetracycline, azithromycin, ampicillin, and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole are commonly used.
  • Shock in diarrhea must be corrected by intravenous fluids only.

Antidiarrhoeals, cardiotonics, antiemetics, antispasmodics, and corticosteroids are not used.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man is diagnosed with cholera. Which of the following drug would you prescribe to his family members to prevent the spread of the disease?
questions.solution:
Tetracycline is the drug of choice for chemoprophylaxis of cholera.

It should be given for:

  • Adults - a 3-day period in a twice-daily dose of 500mg
  • Children (4-13 years) - 125mg
  • Children (0-3 years) - 50mg

Alternatively, the long-acting tetracycline (doxycycline) may be used for chemoprophylaxis, if the prevailing strains are not resistant. A single oral dose of doxycycline (300 mg for adults and 6 mg/kg for children under 15 years) has proved to be effective.

Chemoprophylaxis is advised only for household contacts or a closed community in which cholera has occurred.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most effective prophylactic measure against cholera?
questions.solution:
The most important effective¬†measure against cholera is health education.¬†

The prophylactic measures against cholera include:

  • Health education
  • Food hygiene practices
  • Hand washing practices after defecation
  • Drinking safe water
  • Knowledge about ORS

questions.text: You are a medical officer posted in a village 'X'. The village has been affected by the epidemic of cholera. What is the first step that should be taken to decrease the incidence of the disease?

choices.text: Cholera vaccination to all uninfected individuals
Treat everyone in the village with tetracycline

questions.solution:
Safe water supply and sanitation is the first step to be taken to decrease the incidence of cholera.

Steps taken to decrease the incidence of cholera include:

  • Safe water supply
  • Excreta disposal
  • Food sanitation
  • Disinfection
  • Early case detection

Cholera Vaccines: available in oral forms

  • Dukoral
  • Sanchol and mORCVAX
  • Euvichol
  • Vaxchora
  • CVD103-HgR - no longer produced

Sanchol and Euvichol are available for mass vaccination campaigns. The campaigns have been implemented in areas experiencing an outbreak, in areas at heightened vulnerability during humanitarian crises, and among populations living in highly endemic areas, known as hotspots.

Vaxchora is given for adults (18 – 64 years) who are traveling to an area of active cholera transmission, at least 10 days before the trip.

Mass chemoprophylaxis is not recommended for the control of cholera. This is because the drug's effect is only short-lived (a few days). Moreover, for preventing 1 case of cholera, around 10,000 individuals must be given the drug. Chemoprophylaxis is recommended for only household contacts of confirmed cases with tetracycline.

questions.text: In the ward, a patient with cholera soils the bed with stools. Which chemical should be used to disinfect the bed?
questions.solution:
The most effective disinfectant for cholera stool is a coal tar disinfectant with Riedel-Walker (RW) coefficient of >10 such as cresol.¬†Bleaching powder, if used, should be of good quality.

For disinfection, attention should be paid to the following: patient's stools and vomit; clothes and other contaminated¬†personal items;¬†the latrine,¬†the patient's house, and neighborhood.¬†

questions.text: Cholera is a notifiable disease locally and nationally. Which of the following statements is true regarding the international health regulations for the notification of Cholera?

choices.text: Cholera is notifiable to the WHO by the National Government within 72 hours of its occurence.
The number of cases and deaths are to be reported daily and weekly till the area is declared free of cholera.
An area is declared free of cholera when 1 month has elapsed since the last case.
Mass chemoprophylaxis must be initiated immediately.

questions.solution:
The number of cases and deaths due to cholera are to be reported daily and weekly till the area is declared free of cholera.

International health regulations for the notification of Cholera:

  • Cholera is notifiable to the WHO by the National Government within 24 hours of its occurrence.
  • The number of cases and deaths due to cholera are to be reported daily and weekly till the area is declared free of cholera.
  • When twice the incubation period (5 days) i.e. 10 days has elapsed since the death, recovery, or isolation of the last case, an area is declared free of cholera.
  • Mass prophylaxis is not advised in cholera, as it fails to stop the spread of the disease. Chemoprophylaxis is only advised for household contacts or a closed community.¬†

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy has had 15 episodes of loose stools in the last 24 hours and vomited twice in the last 4 hours. The child is restless and has sunken eyes. On examination, he is irritable but is drinking fluids. What is the optimal therapy for the child?

choices.text: Intravenous fluid initially for 4 hours followed by oral fluids

questions.solution:
Oral rehydration therapy is the optimal therapy to treat acute diarrheas in some dehydration patients.

Recommended formulation: Reduced osmolarity ORS solution, which has a reduced concentration of sodium (75 mmol/liter) and glucose (75 mmol/liter). It helps in reducing the adverse effect of hypertonicity on net fluid absorption.

According to IMNCI guidelines, irritable child who is able to drink fluids come under some dehydration category.

Related Pearl: Composition of reduced osmolarity Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS)

The composition of reduced-osmolarity oral rehydration solution (ORS) is as follows:

Reduced- osmolarity ORS mmol/L
Sodium  75 
Chloride 65
Glucose (anhydrous) 75
Potassium 20
Citrate 10
Total Osmolarity 245

Related Pearl: Symptoms associated with different levels of dehydration

Symptoms No or minimal dehydration Mild to moderate dehydration Severe dehydration
Loss of body weight <3% 3–9% >9%
Mental status Well; alert Fatigued or irritable Lethargic or unconscious
Thirst Drinks normally Thirsty; eager to drink Drinks poorly
Heart rate Normal Normal to increased Tachycardia
Quality of pulse Normal Normal to decreased Weak, thready or impalpable
Skin turgor test Instant recoil Recoil in <2 sec Recoil in >2 sec
Capillary refill Normal Prolonged Prolonged

questions.text: A mother brings her child with complaints of acute diarrhea. After an initial assessment, you diagnose that the child has some dehydration. You counsel the mother to give ORS. After how many hours shall she be advised to discard the old solution and prepare a new one?
questions.solution:
The freshly prepared ORS should not be used after 24 hours.

Guidelines for administering ORS:

  • After each loose stool, give:
    • Children <2 years of age - 50-100 ml (a quarter to half a large cup) of fluid
    • Children 2 to 10 years - 100-200 ml (a half to one large cup)
    • Older children and adults - as much fluid as they want
  • For children <2 years, give a teaspoon every 1 to 2 minutes and offer frequent sips out of a cup for older children. Try to give the estimated required amount within a 4-hour period.
  • If the child vomits, wait for 10 minutes, then give a spoonful every 2 to 3 minutes.
  • If the child wants to drink more ORS solution than the estimated amount and does not vomit, there is no harm in feeding him/her more.
  • If the child is breastfeeding, continue breastfeeding with ORS solution.

questions.text: A baby is brought with complaints of diarrhea and vomiting. The weight of the baby is 12 kgs. What is the estimated amount of fluid to be replaced in 4 hours?
questions.solution:
According to the guidelines of ORS by WHO, a child with a weight of 11-15.9 kg has to be treated with 800-1200 ml of ORS solution within the first 4 hours.

Guidelines for oral rehydration therapy (for all ages) during the first four hours by WHO:

Age  Under 4 months 4-11 months 1-2 yrs 2-4yrs 5-14 yrs 15 yrs or over
Weight (kg) under 5  5-7.9 8-10.9 11-15.9 16-29.9 30 or over
ORS solution (ml) 200-400 400-600 600-800 800-1200 1200-2200 2200-4000

The patient's age should be used if weight is not known.

The approximate amount of ORS required in ml may also be calculated by 75 x body weight (kg).

questions.text: A 9-month-old baby with diarrhea is feeding well and is thirsty. Skin pinch when done returns in 2 seconds. What is the treatment?

choices.text: 200-400 ml of ORS to be given in the first four hours.
400-700 ml of ORS to be given in the first four hours.
700-900 ml of ORS to be given in the first 4 hours.
In addition to the usual fluid intake, 100-200 ml should be given after each loose stool.

questions.solution:
According to the IMNCI classification, the baby has some dehydration and comes under Plan B. The amount of ORS given is 75ml/kg body weight.

Here, the weight of the child is not specified. Hence, 400-700 ml of ORS at home is to be given in the first four hours according to the age of the child. The below table shows the amount of ORS to be given according to the age of the child.

Age under 4 months 4-11 months 1-2 years 2-4 years 5-14 years 15 years and over
Weight(kg) under 5 5-7.9 8-10.9 11-15.9 16-29.9 30 or over
ORS solution (ml) 200-400 400-600 600-800 800-1200 1200-2200 2200-4000

 

In addition to this, 50-100 ml extra fluid is given after each loose stool. After four hours, the baby is reassessed and the appropriate plan is selected again for the continuation of the treatment.

The four rules of home treatment are:

  • Give extra fluid
  • Give zinc supplements (1 tablet per day for 14 days, dissolved in a small amount of ORS or breast milk or clean water)
  • Continue breastfeeding
  • Counsel the mother to return if there is blood in stools and if the child is feeding poorly

Related Pearl: Treatment of dehydration based on severity

Plan A: For no dehydration or minimal dehydration. ORS is administered after each loose stool.

Age Amount 
<2 years 50–100 mL
2-10 years 100–200 mL
>10 years As much fluid as they want

Plan B: For moderate dehydration.

The amount of oral rehydration solution (ORS) to be given is 75 mL/kg body weight (wt × 75).

Plan C: Severe dehydration

Age First, give 30 mL/kg in Followed by 70 mL/kg in Total 100 mL/kg in
Infants (under 12 months) 1 hr 5 hrs  6 hrs
Older 30 min 2½ hrs  3 hrs

Note: Ringer lactate (ideal) or normal saline is used as intravenous fluids.

questions.text: Which among the following home remedies are not advised for a child with diarrhea?

choices.text: A mixture of 1 teaspoon of  salt and 6 teaspoons of sugar in 1 L of drinking water
Unsalted water in which a cereal has been cooked
Soup with 3g/litre salt added to it

questions.solution:
Salted water in which cereal has been cooked can be given to a child with diarrhoea.

If the WHO ORS mixture is not available, a simple mixture of 1 teaspoon of salt and 6 teaspoons of sugar must be dissolved in 1 L of drinking water and given to the child.

Fluids that do not contain salt in water, for eg: rice water, unsalted soup, yoghurt drinks, green coconut water, etc, must not be given. 3g/litre of salt must be added to such drinks before giving it to the child with diarrhoea.

The infant's usual diet of cereals, vegetables and other foods should be continued and never be diluted. The child should be given as much nutrient-rich food as acceptable.

Avoid the following:

  • Sweetened drinks with sugar, like commercial fruit juices and sweetened tea, as they lead to osmotic diarrhoea and hypernatremia.
  • Fluids with a stimulant and purgative effect like coffee and medicinal tea infusions.

questions.text: A child with severe dehydration is being treated with intravenous fluids for the past 2 hours. Which of the following will be used as an early indicator for adequate rehydration?
questions.solution:
Skin elasticity and pulse strength are the most helpful indicators for adequate intravenous rehydration.

The urine output may be unchanged even after 3-4 hours of adequate rehydration. Hence, it cannot be a criterion for continuous examination.

The initial rehydration must be fast until an easily palpable pulse is present. Reassess the patient every 1-2 hours.

After 1-2 liters of fluid have been infused, the drip should be slowed down till the blood pressure and pulse return to normal. Rehydration must be continued otherwise till all signs of dehydration have disappeared. ORS should be given when the patient can drink oral fluids.

Puffy eyelids are a sign of excess rehydration and intravenous fluids must be stopped when it occurs.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy is referred from a sub-center due to a feeble pulse and low BP. The patient has had diarrhea for 2 days. He has sunken eyes and is lethargic. On examination, BP is 90/60 mmHg. Which of the following fluids cannot be used for resuscitation in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has severe dehydration which is treated by giving IV fluids. Plain glucose and dextrose solutions should not be used as they worsen the hyperosmolar state.

Intravenous rehydration: Used for initial rehydration for patients in shock or those who are unable to drink.

  • Ringer's lactate solution/Hartmann's solution - Used for injection. Best commercially available solution. 
  • Diarrhea treatment solution- Recommended as an ideal polyelectrolyte solution for intravenous infusion.
  • Normal saline- Used if nothing else is available. It is the poorest fluid, as it does not correct the acidosis and will not replace the potassium losses.

questions.text: What is the recommended dosage for zinc supplements in children with diarrhea?

choices.text: 20 mg of zinc daily for infants < 12 months of age for 10-14 days
20 mg of zinc for children > 6 months of age for 7 days
10 mg of zinc for children > 12 months of age for 20 days
10 mg of zinc for children < 6 months of age for 10-14 days

questions.solution:
According to WHO and UNICEF, 10 mg of zinc is given to infants < 6 months of age for 10-14 days.

20 mg of Zinc is given to infants > 6 months of age for 10-14 days during an episode of acute diarrhoea. This is done to reduce the duration and severity of the episode and prevent recurrence in the following months.

Intensified Diarrhea Control Fortnight : The goal is to attain zero child deaths due to childhood diarrhea. The overall objective of IDCF is to ensure high coverage of ORS and Zinc use rates in children with diarrhoea. It also complements awareness activities (including Swachh) for prevention and management of diarrhoea in under-five children.

questions.text: For a child with SAM, what should be the sodium content of his rehydration fluid?
questions.solution:
The sodium content of the rehydration solution to treat SAM is 45mmol/L.

ReSoMal (rehydration solution for malnourished children) contains a lower amount of sodium (45mmol/L) and a higher amount of potassium (40 mmol/L) than the standard WHO-ORS.

ReSoMal is used in in-patient centers for the treatment of children with severe acute malnutrition (SAM). It is useful in correcting hypokalemia, and in lowering the risks of excess sodium and/or overhydration.

Composition of ReSoMal and ORS:

Component (mmol/l) Standard ORS ReSoMal
Glucose 75 (anhydrous) 125
Sodium 75 45
Potassium 20 40
Chloride 65 70
Citrate  10 7
Magnesium - 3
Zinc - 0.3
Copper - 0.045
Osmolality 245 300

questions.text: What is the average incubation period of typhoid fever?
questions.solution:
The average incubation period of typhoid is 10-14 days.

However, it can vary from 3 days to 3 weeks depending on the dose of bacilli ingested.

questions.text: In a boys hostel, there has been an outbreak of typhoid. The hostel cook is identified as the carrier of the disease. Which is true among the following statements regarding her condition?

choices.text: Gallbladder is usually not involved in carrier state
Chronic carriers are those who excrete the bacilli for more than a year
Tetracycline is the drug of choice for carriers
To treat the carrier state, treatment should be given for 4 weeks

questions.solution:
Chronic carriers of typhoid are those who excrete the bacilli for more than a year.

Convalescent carriers excrete bacilli for 6-8 weeks and chronic carriers excrete for more than a year. The carrier rate in females is higher. Gallbladder and biliary tract are affected. 

To treat the carrier state, an intensive course of ampicillin or amoxicillin (4-6 g a day) together with Probenecid (2 g/day) for 6 weeks is given. Cholecystectomy with concomitant ampicillin therapy is the most successful treatment for the carrier state.

questions.text: In which of the following patients can the Ty21a vaccine be administered?

choices.text: A 50-year-old HIV patient who is asymptomatic with CD4+ count 240/mm3
A 42-year-old patient with fever and cough for 3 days
A 64-years-old alcoholic on colchicine therapy for acute gout

questions.solution:
Ty21a vaccine can be administered in an HIV-positive asymptomatic patient as long as the CD4+ count is >200/ cubic mm. 

Ty21a is an oral vaccine for individuals ≥5 years of age. It is given in 3 doses on the 1st, 3rd, and 5th day. Repeat every 3 years for endemic areas, and every year for traveling individuals. 

It is not recommended in:

  • Patients on antimitotic drugs and immunosuppressants
  • Acute febrile illness
  • Acute intestinal infestation

Proguanil and antibacterial drugs should be stopped from 3 days before to 3 days after the vaccine.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding dracunculiasis?

choices.text: Niridazole prevents transmission of the disease.
The disease is limited to tropical and subtropical regions.
No animal reservoir has been proved.

questions.solution:
Niridazole does not prevent transmission of the disease. 

Dracunculiasis is treated by removing the worm by sequentially rolling them out over a small stick. Wet compresses may relieve discomfort. Occlusive dressings limit shedding of infectious larvae.

Metronidazole and mebendazole are used to limit inflammation and facilitate worm removal.

Dracunculiasis or Guinea-worm disease is amenable to eradication. The eradication strategy comprises the following elements :

  • Provision of safe drinking water.
  • Control of cyclops.
  • Health education regarding drinking boiled water.
  • Surveillance: Active search for new cases.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about hookworms?

choices.text: Blood loss due to Necator americanus infection is more compared to Ancylostoma infection.
Malnutrition is a predisposing factor for this chronic disabling disease.
Chandler‚Äôs index is used in epidemiological studies of hookworm.
Chronic blood loss in pregnant women may lead to abortions, stillbirth and low birth weight babies.

questions.solution:
The blood loss due to Ancylostoma (0.2 ml/day) is more compared to Necatur americanus (0.03ml/day)

Malnutrition is a predisposing factor. The chronic disabling disease does not occur in individuals who are well-nourished and whose iron intake is adequate.

Chandler's index is used to identify importance of hookworm infestation as a public health problem. It is calculated as average number of hookworm eggs/gram of stool. 

  • <200: no significance
  • 200-250: the potential danger
  • 250-300: minor public health problem
  • >300: major public health problem

Hookworm inection causes chronic blood loss and depletion of body's iron stores leading to iron deficiency anemia. This in pregnant women can lead to abortions, stillbirth and low birth weight babies.
